channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Virus Is Killing Young Floridians. Race Is a Big Factor.
item.description: The number of younger adults in the state who died of the disease quadrupled last month, as rising numbers of them tested positive.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Robert Gebeloff, Danielle Ivory and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

item.title: New York Accuses Egg Producer of Price Gouging in Pandemic
item.description: New Yorkers may have paid quadruple what they should have for eggs at a time when virus cases were surging, according to a lawsuit by the state attorney general’s office.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:description: Several lawsuits have been filed accusing major egg producers of illegally taking advantage of heightened demand brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: In the Wake of Covid-19 Lockdowns, a Troubling Surge in Homicides
item.description: “People have gotten to the point where they just don’t give a damn,” said a minister in Kansas City, which is on pace for a record number of killings.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Shaila Dewan and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: A pedestrian crosses a downtown street in Kansas City, Mo.

item.title: ‘Can’t Do It’: Chief Resigns Amid Seattle’s Divide Over Policing
item.description: As cities try to cut back on traditional policing, Seattle has embarked on one of the nation’s most ambitious plans. The Black woman who leads the department is stepping down in frustration.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Dean Rutz/The Seattle Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police Chief Carmen Best is the first Black woman to hold the top policing job in Seattle.

item.title: Biden and Harris’s Incident-Free, Audience-Free Debut
item.description: For all the oddities endemic to a mid-virus presidential campaign, the pair’s maiden gathering reflected a scene that seemed entirely plausible, even predictable, a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:description: The candidates stood with their spouses and maintained social distancing at the end of their debut event together.

item.title: Black Women Asked Their Party for What They Wanted. What Happens After the Kamala Harris Pick?
item.description: Kamala Harris is the first woman of color on a major party ticket. For the women who helped get her here, the moment is joyful, and worrisome.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Evan Nicole Brown
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Halliestine Zimmerman at her home in Mauldin, S.C., in 2019. “Finally,” she said of the Democrats, “they are letting us know they hear us.”

item.title: Ohio State Football Is Canceled. Will Trump Take the Hit?
item.description: The Big Ten Conference’s decision to cancel its football season reverberated across Ohio, where the Buckeyes’ football program looms large. Some voters blamed President Trump’s handling of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: College football serves as an autumn religion on campus and in rural areas of battleground states like Ohio where President Trump’s support runs deepest.

item.title: G.O.P.'s Raw Personal Attacks on Kamala Harris
item.description: ‘Radical leftist’ or not progressive enough? In the hours after Ms. Harris’s announcement as Joe Biden’s vice president, the Trump campaign struggled to launch a clear attack on the Biden-Harris ticket.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday. On Wednesday he took aim at Senator Kamala Harris after her announcement as Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s running mate.

item.title: How Big a Role Will Kamala Harris Get to Play?
item.description: As Ms. Harris joins the Democratic ticket, the question now is how much power she will wield over the campaign and in office.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee for President, and Senator Kamala Harris, his newly announced running mate, hold their first news event together at Alexis Dupont High School in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Biden and Harris Pledge a Strong Challenge to Trump and a Path Out of Crisis
item.description: Joe Biden and Kamala Harris made their debut as running mates in Wilmington, Del., offering a vision of recovery from the coronavirus and pressing their case that the president has made things worse at every turn.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Kamala Harris appeared together for the first time as running mates in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: Health Experts Warn About Perils of New Virus Data Collection System
item.description: An administration shift is putting a burden on hospitals and undercutting the integrity of data on the pandemic, current and former members of a federal advisory panel said.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A nurse checking on a Covid-19 patient last month at Houston Methodist Hospital. The Trump administration recently ordered hospitals to use a new system for tracking coronavirus patient data.

item.title: G.O.P.ers Can’t Find Their Kamala
item.description: The attacks from Trump’s allies just don’t seem to fit.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Administration Reaches Out to Democrats on Stimulus Bill
item.description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin talked with Speaker Nancy Pelosi for the first time since negotiations on a new coronavirus relief bill collapsed, but neither side showed any willingness to budge.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re miles apart,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: One Georgia district might foretell the chaos of the coming semester.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Why One Activist Injured in Charlottesville Won’t Give Up
item.description: For Constance Paige Young, who was among the counterprotesters injured in Charlottesville, it is a moral obligation to continue showing up.
item.dc:creator: Fahima Haque
item.media:credit: Ryan M. Kelly/Daily Progress, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A car drove into a group of protesters demonstrating against a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017.

item.title: Air Force Helicopter Shot Over Virginia Forced to Make Emergency Landing, F.B.I. Says
item.description: One crew member was treated at a hospital for injuries that were not life-threatening, according to the authorities, who said they were investigating the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A U.S. Air Force helicopter like this one was hit by a bullet during a training exercise in Virginia this week.

item.title: A Florida Sheriff Has Ordered His Deputies Not to Wear Masks
item.description: The sheriff forbade his deputies from wearing masks while on duty, with some exceptions, and also barred visitors to his offices from wearing them.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: More states and cities are moving to require face coverings. In Miami Beach, Fla., above, officials have issued more than $14,000 in fines to people who have refused to wear masks.

item.title: Progressives Didn’t Want Harris for V.P. They’re Backing Her Anyway.
item.description: Joe Biden’s selection of Kamala Harris reaffirmed progressives’ fears of a Biden administration rooted in establishment politics. But rather than revolt, many snuffed out their criticisms.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Astead W. Herndon
item.media:description: In choosing Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr. opted for a moderate ideological ally.

item.title: Two Indianapolis Police Officers Charged With Assaulting Protesters
item.description: The two were indicted after videos taken by TV crews showed officers repeatedly striking one woman with batons and shoving another to the ground, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: James Harris, Towering Wrestler Known as Kamala, Dies at 70
item.description: He became a top draw portraying a stereotypical menacing African warrior who was always supposed to lose to his white opponents. He died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Google, Facebook and Others Broaden Group to Secure U.S. Election
item.description: More tech companies met with government agencies on Wednesday to fight disinformation on social media.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Several major tech companies will work with government agencies as a group to fight disinformation like the QAnon conspiracy theory, represented by the Q on supporters’ phones.

item.title: With the Biden-Harris Ticket, Environmental Justice Is a Focus
item.description: Climate change leaders said the choice of Harris signaled that Democrats will try to ensure that communities burdened by pollution would benefit from a transition to clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Climate Equity Act, a bill co-sponsored in the Senate last year by Kamala Harris, would require the government to rate the effects of environmental rules on low-income communities.

item.title: Confidence in Police Is at Record Low, Gallup Survey Finds
item.description: For the first time in its 27 years of measuring attitudes toward the police, Gallup found that a majority of American adults do not trust law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest in Chicago in July. Gallup began tracking public confidence in the police in 1993.

item.title: Kamala Harris Crystallizes Trump’s View of Women
item.description: As Ms. Harris joined the Democratic ticket, the president wasted no time calling her “nasty” and praising the “suburban housewife” he says will vote for him. His views are out of step with reality.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: A Trump rally in January in Toledo, Ohio.

item.title: Regrets? Even Brent Scowcroft Had a Few
item.description: In an oral history released after his death, the former national security adviser revealed a few key moments in which his ideas failed in the war against Saddam Hussein.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Brent Scowcroft’s public warning against the second Iraq war cemented his place as a voice of establishment restraint and one of the last of his generation’s wise men.

item.title: Woody Johnson Asked State Dept. Auditors to Delete Claims of Offensive Remarks From Report
item.description: The American ambassador to Britain rejected accusations that he made racially or sexually inappropriate comments toward employees at the U.S. Embassy in London.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Mark Landler
item.media:description: In a letter, Robert Wood Johnson IV, the American ambassador to Britain, said he rejected claims that he may have violated embassy employees’ civil rights.

item.title: Advisers Consider Whether Trump Can Cut Taxes Without Congress
item.description: Trump’s lawyers and economic advisers have studied how far they could stretch executive authority to set tax policy, though the legality of any cuts is dubious.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: President Trump’s advisers have sought legal guidance from White House lawyers about whether the president has the authority to eliminate certain taxes.

item.title: What Kamala Harris's Nomination Means for California
item.description: Wednesday: Senator Kamala Harris is officially Joe Biden’s vice-presidential pick. Also: The Pac-12 won’t play football in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris, flanked by Mayor Libby Schaaf of Oakland, left, and Representative Barbara Lee, right, at the opening of her presidential campaign office in Oakland in September.

item.title: Ilhan Omar’s primary victory gives progressives another boost.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rep. Ilhan Omar waved to passing traffic with staff and supporters in Minneapolis, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump’s push to cut payroll taxes has opened a Democratic line of attack.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:description: President Donald Trump during a news conference in the White House briefing room on Tuesday.

item.title: Here are four big tasks Biden and Harris face in their first appearance.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Supporters gathered outside the venue in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: The V.P. choice was both conventional and groundbreaking.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
item.media:description: Both Harris and Biden have hewed closely to their party’s mainstream for years, shifting left with the times but always with an eye on the broader electorate and higher office.

item.title: A QAnon supporter is (almost definitely) heading to Congress.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg, Astead W. Herndon and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, center, with supporters at an event in Rome, Ga., on Tuesday night. She beat a Republican who is no less conservative or pro-Trump, but does not support QAnon.

item.title: Geographic balance takes a back seat to gender and race.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher, Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina

item.title: What the Harris Pick Means
item.description: Can a cautious V.P. choice jolt a campaign? Biden’s going to see. This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens

item.title: The Biden-Harris Ticket
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar

item.title: Live Coronavirus News Updates
item.description: A group of 34 health experts warned about the perils of new U.S. rules on virus data collection. New Zealand reported more local transmissions.

item.title: Georgia School District Quarantines Nearly 1,200 Students and Teachers
item.description: A suburban Atlanta county opened its schools amid controversy and a growing case count, previewing a difficult national back-to-school season.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at a number of schools in the Cherokee County School District in Georgia, including Hasty Elementary, have tested positive for the coronavirus during the first week of school.

item.title: Charleston Tourism Is Built on Southern Charm. Locals Say It’s Time to Change.
item.description: A powerful visitors’ bureau has pushed the South Carolina city to the top of “best” lists by selling gentility. Critics say that has come at the expense of history and the city’s Black population.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa and Kim Severson
item.media:credit: Hunter McRae for The New York Times
item.media:description: Businesses along King Street in Charleston, S.C., were damaged during a Black Lives Matter protest, but the local visitors' bureau told members to post only “uplifting and positive content.”

item.title: Infertility Was Distressing. The Military Made It Even More Complicated.
item.description: For service members like me, Tricare health insurance and the limited number of military medical facilities offering fertility treatments add more stress to an already emotional process.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Chamberlin
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center
item.media:description: Victoria Chamberlin during her farewell ceremony from The U.S. Army Band “Pershing’s Own” in December.

item.title: QAnon Followers Are Hijacking the #SaveTheChildren Movement
item.description: Fans of the pro-Trump conspiracy theory are clogging anti-trafficking hotlines, infiltrating Facebook groups and raising false fears about child exploitation.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman holding up a hat with a Q on it, denoting QAnon, at a 2018 rally for President Trump.

item.title: The Nation Wanted to Eat Out Again. Everyone Has Paid the Price.
item.description: Governments and restaurant owners wanted to get back to business. But bars and restaurants have become a focal point for clusters of Covid infections.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Socially distanced tables with sneeze guards separating booths at Pinewood Social.

item.title: Kamala Harris, a Political Fighter Shaped by Life in Two Worlds
item.description: She grew up around Berkeley activists but came to believe working from inside the system had greater power to effect change.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer and Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris’s early experiences pushed her away from outsider politics and into the Democratic establishment.
